reviewText: A standard WWII double agent with knowledge of D-Day plans type film. Made in Europe in the 1980s, so the color is beautiful, the visual locations are mostly the correct place, and so on. But, the modernizations of the then 40 years since the war are visible in some shots, but not many due to some careful camera work and set dressing. Likewise on some of the language used. And the civilian clothing of the two male leads appears to be off the pages of GQ magazine. Nazi uniforms look right ( No..authentic is the word...nobody can say anything about the Nazis was right!), and all vehicles seem to be correct vintage and set-up. Casting brings three male leads...Horst Bucholtz (Magnificent 7) as SS Colonel and "nice Guy" (?); Max von Sydow  (lots of movies, such as "Victory") as a German (not Nazi) intelligence officer (another nice guy?); and Ed Harris (right out of "The Right Stuff" as John Glenn) as the American double agent the Jerries are so nice to. Eric Stolz at age 21 is an American Lt. POW the Germans are not being too nice to because he, for whatever reason, is privy to the Normany time table and plans...right... Oh, and Patrick Stewart, pre-STNG Captain Piccard, is here too...in a British army uniform...and hair on his sidewalls before he went the Q-ball haircut route).This was a movie made for cable by MGM and NBC enterprises. It was on Cinemax in 1984-85. It's predictable as all get out, but it moves along, has nice scenery, some unique airplanes in it, is historical fiction, and fun to view. My DVD came to me quickly and in perfect condition. If you share my intetests and attitudes (see my other reviews), you'll probably like ths too.
summary: Really? That many Nazis as Good Guys? Riiightt!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Do not read the above editiorial review  if you want to fully appreciate this film, as it gives away the plot. Ed Harris plays an American spy, Gus Lang. He  works for both the British and Germans during the period immediately before DDAY. He is sent to Paris where a young but brilliant American officer, one of a handful of allied soldiers who knows the actual DDay plans, has been  captured and is being interrogated by the Germans. The Allies direct Lang to prevent the young American from talking. The Germans use Lang to try coercing the American to reveal the Allies DDay plans. The fun of this movie revolves around  not knowing Gus Lang's real intentions. Add the fact that one of the German officers involved in the interogation is working for the Allies, but which one? This is a smart, well written script, with strong characters by a fine cast.
summary: Do Not  Read the Editorial Review

reviewText: Horst played a Nazi, the second film where he portrayed a Nazi soldier. He had aged but it was near the end of his career. I liked the movie very much. A good transfer and probably only available on Amazon. He was a fine actor and I miss his performances very much. There are a couple other movies on Amazon that he made in Germany. In addition to the fantastic FANNY.
summary: Horst Buchholtz in his latter years.
